subject: RE: [junit] Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?
msgSnippet: ... mindless ... written, ... bad ... already ... for ... the ...  Well, yes and no. You said, I agree... but
messageBody:
<quote name="Hoepner, Josh (J.M.)">

><quote>
>...let's not forget that testing is a mindful activity, and not a
mindless
>activity. Generating test stubs, especially from classes already
written,
>relieves you of the need to think about what you're testing. This is a
bad
>thing, and often a Bad Thing.
></quote>
>
>I agree wholeheartedly with what you're saying. Unfortunately, I was
>given the dubious honor of creating JUnit tests for code that was
already
>written. The test stub generator saves me alot of time creating stubs
for
>methods that have 80+ <ack!> methods. Then I go through and remove
the
>stubs for methods that don't need to be tested and add test cases for
>methods that are more complex and require multiple test cases. Stub
>generation is a timesaver IMHO, as long as you make sure you are still
>covering all your bases.
</quote>

Well, yes and no. You said, "I agree..." but then argued the other side
of the issue, and I'm just trying to explore that.

I presume you work somewhat like this:

1. Pick a class.
2. Generate test stubs.
3. For each test stub:
3.1. "Hm... do I need this?" Delete if "no", otherwise:
3.2. Write the test.
3.3. Make it pass, if it doesn't already.

My guess is, though, that as you "make it pass", you have to change
things. You may even add and remove methods to make the code you're
testing pass or to make it easier to understand. (If you truly can't do
this for whatever reason, then let me know, because then the rules
change a little.) This may invalidate a good portion of step 2. In that
case, perhaps better is to skip step 2 *or* see whether you can
generate test stubs for only one method or group of overloaded methods
at a time.

If it really is working for you, then great; but maybe you're falling
for automation: "I'll automate it, and change whatever I need to change
afterward." That's a good idea, but only if you're changing less than
say, half the wor the automation is doing for you.

By the way -- you have classes with 80 methods? Can you do some
braindead refactorings first, like extract class, to make that more
manageable? There are some refactorings that you can apply -- if you do
so very carefully -- without tests, although that's not necessarily
recommended. :)

Good luck,

>
>-Josh
